reviews.author: Small_Potato
reviews.title: Interesting introductory course to modern physics with some very smart IRE people
reviews.comment_content:
A required course for minoring physics/astrophysics.

Syllabus:
1. Special relativity (E)
2. General relativity (A)
3. From action to laws of nature (A)
4. Quantum mechanics (E)
5. Quantum information (A)
6. Atoms and molecules (E)
7. Statistical physics (A)
8. Complexity (A, No time to teach)
9. Nuclear and particle physics (A, No time to teach)
10. Cosmology (A)
E: Essential Part, A: Advanced Part

The essential parts determine whether you get A range or not, while the advanced parts determine whether you get A-, A or A+.

The course covers a very wide range of topics, but professor does not go in too deep for each of them. Having some knowledge on linear algebra and differential equations will help you a bit on understanding some of the math-heavy concepts such as spin states. Calculus is very important for this course too.

In general, the contents can get quite hard to understand when it comes to things like "potential barriers and wells", "principle of least action" and "Bell's inequality", at least for me. Therefore, it is advised that you re-watch the lecture videos and try to understand as much as possible. One good thing is that once you understood the concepts, you do not need to spend much time to prepare for the midterms and finals.

There are some practice exercises at the end of each lecture notes. However, no answers will be posted and they will only be discussed in tutorial sessions. Some of them may appear in the finals and midterm too.

Also, you do not need any knowledge from PHYS1114 to survive in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching was really good. Prof. WANG is a very enthusiastic professor and his explanation of concepts is clear to me. For me, I find it a bit difficult to catch up to what he says in lesson because he talks rather slow at easier parts and a bit fast at harder parts. So, what I did was watch the lecture videos and adjust the speed at certain parts. Prof. WANG occasionally makes jokes (which are actually funny) to lighten up the mood. Also, he wore the Einstein T-shirt and Schrodinger's T-shirt to class as a way to cheer us up. Professor also has a spare hour after class and he ends the lesson early, so students can find him for questions.

I think that the lecture notes are pretty detailed, with some good illustrations to make things easier to understand. There are clear subheadings and extra explanation on the sides. Sometimes there may be typos so be mindful of that.

As for the tutorials, I attended the first few but I find it a bit difficult to understand what the TA said so in the end I just gave up and skip all the tutorials. No attendance will be taken.

There is also a Facebook group which you can join and ask some questions there too.

reviews.comment_workload:
There are only 4 pieces of homework for the whole course. The 1st (Special Relativity) and 4th (Atoms) one are relatively easy, but the 2nd (Lagrangian) and 3rd (Potential Barrier) one can really hurt your brain and they are math-heavy. Homework is also divided into Essential and Advanced, so if you are not aiming for A or A+, you can ignore those Advanced homework. Usually, what I do is I search online for similar questions so I can get an idea of what is the correct approach to the questions. For the 2nd homework, it may take you an hour or so just to write a few lines, so prepared to be frustrated. Of course, if you are one of those IRE geniuses, then you can ignore what I have just said.

For the lectures, it is alright if you skip them. However, be prepared to watch the lecture videos multiple times as some concepts and math can really mess up your brain. I highlighted the important points and added my own notes to the lecture notes. Took me quite some time.

For midterm and finals, you can bring 1 double-sided A4 cheatsheet to each of them. Instead of just cramming the derivations and formulas in the cheatsheet, try to also understand the concepts behind, as conceptual questions also take up a large portion of the exams. MC takes up 30/70 of Essential Part and 10/30 of Advanced part.

reviews.author: Sean Lau
reviews.comment_content:
Essential:
Special relativity
Quantum mechanics
Atoms and molecules

Additional (optional):
General relativity
Action/Lagrangian Mechanics
Quantum information/entanglement
Statistical physics/entropy
Condensed matter
Complexity
Nuclear and particle physics
Cosmology

Essential content will be used to determine your general grade, with the exception of the A range sub-grades. If your score from the essential part is high enough to reach A range, then your A sub-grade (e.g. A-, A, A+) will be determined from the additional content.

The main essential topics are special relativity and quantum mechanics. Special relativity was quite easy, but I found the later parts of quantum mechanics to be quite difficult. The derivations used in atoms and molecules is also very hard to follow.

The additional topics may in fact be easier than than most of the essential topics (with the exception of special relativity, which is the easiest). However, not all additional topics will be taught. During 2017-18 fall, only general relativity, action, quantum information/entanglement, and statistical physics/entropy were taught as the additional topics, as there wasn't enough time to cover the others.

As there are so many different topics, there is a LOT of content covered in this course (although not too deep). Because of this, it may be difficult to keep up with the lectures' contents unless you revise after every single topic.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Wang is very enthusiastic in his teaching and encourages students to ask questions. He often stays behind after lectures for students to ask him questions. His lectures are quite interesting as he often includes short anecdotes and jokes.

However, sometimes it is difficult to keep up with the mathematical derivations that he writes on the whiteboard.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is very good. I achieved mediocre scores for the essential parts but still managed to get an A.
reviews.comment_workload:
The work required for this course is minimal, as there are only 3 assignments over the semester (including 2 essential, 1 additional).

However, I personally had to spend a lot of time revising for this course simply due to the huge amount of content that it covers.

11. Cosmology (1, A)

Numbers in mean the expected number of lectures for each topic. Letter E means "Essential" part and letter A means "Advanced" part (these decide grading). Remark IF means only taught if time permits.

"Essential" material is pretty much all covered in Prof. Wang's lecture notes. "Advanced" material would require you own further reading for better understanding. In our semester, the "IF" topics were not taught.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Wang is very enthusiastic and engaging in teaching. He tries to explain the physics in an accessible way, due to the low prequisite requirements on the course. However, some relevant knowledge in mathematics (linear algebra and differential equations) would be helpful for understanding derivations.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments 20%
Midterm 35%
Final 45%

"Essential" part decides grading for A-range and B-F. "Advanced" part helps in grading within the A-range. I remember the professor saying that "Advanced" material counts for 30% of the A-range grading, so it is still possible to score high in the A-range with "Essential" part alone albeit unlikely. Also, if your "Essential" score is too low, then the "Advanced" score does not matter for grade.

Midterm and final have some multiple choice questions, which are quite straightforward. Then some short answer problems that either require written explanation or mathematical derivation. For assignments, turning in a satisfactory solution will result in full score; the marking is undemanding.
reviews.comment_workload:
There is not much workload, only some assignments. The three assignments for our semester were on the topics of Special Relativity, Action Principle, and Quantum Mechanics.

Most of "Essential" information is covered in Prof. Wang's lecture notes. However, the "Advanced" questions in midterm and final seem to expect students to have further knowledge than just the notes.

reviews.author: tdhvl
reviews.comment_content:
The purpose of this course is to give an initial taste about how modern physics is like so it covers many different topic but only introduce simple ideas and basic concepts.

There are three essential topics: Special relativity, Quantum mechanics and Atoms and molecules. These topics are the most fundamental and the easiest parts of this course. They constitute the majority of the examinations and assignments. The remaining topics are labeled as advanced as they are harder to understand. The professor only try to give some simple examples but not entirely the full picture of these topics. The advanced topics are: General relativity, Action, Quantum entanglement, Entropy and Information, Cosmology.

At the end of each topic, the professor often introduces useful resources to learn deeper the corresponding topics. You can enhance yourself by reading those materials to prepare for advanced courses and for research activities, but this is not necessary to get a good grade in this course.

This course requires a good imagination to understand some new concepts, which could be a little bit confusing at the beginning.
The mathematical tools involved are just elementary algebra, calculus and a little bit of complex numbers. All steps involving mathematical tools other than elementary algebra and calculus during the proofs are listed as optional and will not be asked in examinations. Therefore, I think that first-year students can enroll in this course with no problems.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Wang is a good instructor. He explains carefully steps by steps and can introduce the content in humorous ways, making the lessons more relaxing. After each lecture, the professor often spend about 10 minutes answering questions.

The tutorial classes are conducted by TAs. The TAs will usually solve some exercises in the lecture notes and show some videos about the topics learned in the lecture classes.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading of this course is very generous. During the course, the professor made a survey to decide the grading method. This year, the majority voted to use the scores in essential parts to determine the A-range and 70% essential + 30% advanced to determine the sub-grade (A+, A, A-). If the essential score is not high enough to attain A-range, then the advanced score would be meaningless. As the essential part is easy, many people got A-range. I don't know the cutoff for A+ grades. However, I guess that around 8 people get an A+ grade.

The grading is based on 6 assignments (5 points each) and the midterm exam. The score is calculated by 50% assignments + 50% midterm exam.

The midterm statistics is provided in the attached image.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is very light. The assignments are easy and are released every 3 weeks.

The professor does not take attendance and what he said in the class is identical to things written in the lecture notes. Therefore, you can save time by reading lecture notes and not coming to class if you are confident.

reviews.author: Roy Sukjin Mun
reviews.title: An unorthodox modern physics class
reviews.comment_content:
Course Syllabus:
1. Special Relativity (Essential)
2. General Relativity (Advanced)
3. Action Principle (Advanced)
4. Quantum Mechanics (Essential)
5. Quantum Entanglement (Advanced)
6. Atoms (Essential)
7. Entropy and Information (Advanced)
8. A 30 minutes introduction to cosmology at the very end of this course, but not tested in the exams

Lecture notes are very irritating to read. Those who believe the lecture notes are well made, then they either have not understood the physics or are simply bluffing. In fact, the bad quality of the lecture notes should be more apparent to those who have already learnt the materials. The concepts are introduced in subtle ways, wordings are usually unclear and derivations are often hand-wavy. I understand that theorists in general are not aware of the boundary between "introductory level" and "advanced level", but I cannot agree that the lecture notes are good especially for an introductory class. Students must attend the lectures (or watch the uploaded videos on Canvas) in order to fully understand what the professor was trying to say in the lecture notes. Professor Wang updates his lecture notes every year, so hopefully he will improve his writing for the updated versions.

In addition, most recommended readings at the back of the lecture notes are baffling. For instance, Principles of Quantum Mechanics by Shankar, Modern Quantum Mechanics by Sakurai, Classical Mechanics by Goldstein are definitely not for students who have just started learning sophomore-level physics in an introductory modern physics class. I therefore personally recommend more suitable readings that may be helpful for the beginners to understand the lecture notes (at least minimally, even the list below may not be sufficient sometimes. As I said, the lecture notes are absurd. Some do overlap with what lecture note recommends). These references, including the solution manuals, are readily available online:

<Special Relativity> + <General Relativity>
Introduction to Electrodynamics by Griffiths - Chapter 12.1-12.2
A General Relativity Workbook by Brown - just a few beginning chapters correspondent to the contents of the lecture note
Astrophysics Processes by Hale Bradt - chapter 7, beginning sections before relativity in electrodynamics. It has the most elegant proofs I have seen on a textbook so far.

<Action Principle>
Mechanics by Landau, Chapter 1
The Feynman Lectures On Physics, Vol 1, Chapter 26

<Quantum Mechanics>
Introduction to Quantum Mechanics by Griffiths, Chapter 1-4
Quantum Physics of Atoms, Molecules, Solids, Nuclei, and Particles by Elsberg, (if you find even the mathematics in Griffiths is hard, just read through this until you grasp the concept and then go back to Griffiths)

<Entropy and Information>
Concepts in Thermal Physics by Blundell, Chapter 4, Example 4.1 (The example explains the concept of microstates clearly. The definition of microstates is overlooked in the lecture note. Other than this, reading through the lecture note is enough)

Please note to always go back to wrap up the lecture notes as well when you rely on external references, as some problems in the exams were directly from the exercise questions at the back of lecture notes & understanding of the contents on the lecture notes.

For reference, the exercise questions are included as attachments below. These questions were easier than (or maybe somewhat similar to) the actual exams in this semester. However, some exercise questions are poorly designed, irrelevant to the course contents (exercise 6 for instance, was not included in the course syllabus).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Wang is enthusiastic about teaching. He always answers questions during the lecture and after the class. He also makes jokes in mandarin to make students engaged. His explanations are not always clear, but students can direcly ask him for clarifications.

The tutorials are taught by the TAs. I chose not to attend the tutorials as I could barely understand the TA's English.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading seems to be fair, but the grading scheme is quite aberrant.

The final grade is based on
Assignments (3 in total, a long answer question for each. 20%)
Mid-Term (35%, Special Relativity - peripheral contents of Quantum Mechanics)
Final (45%, Quantum Mechanics - Entropy and Information)

If one does not get an A range grade for the Essential parts, then he will not be able to get above B+ for the final grade regardless of the grade earned in the Advanced sections.

I suppose the difficulty of the exams in this semester has been significantly reduced compared to those of the past. I have looked through the past mid-term exam papers (2014, 2015 and 2016, if I recall correctly), and some problems in these exams required firm understanding in general relativity. In contrast, the questions in this year were much more straightforward (to the point that if you have been to class consistently, the professor has simply told you some answers for the mid-term & final).   

Consistently scoring full marks in assignments and above mean for both mid-term and final (as mentioned, the essential parts need to be above mean) will give one an easy A for the final grade (my final percentage score on the Canvas is 88%, which is equivalent to A). I am not sure about the boundary for an A+.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload will be different depending on the student's academic background in physics. However, even if one has never studied relativity and quantum mechanics, the level of workload in general should be somewhat moderate (only in terms of the essential parts). The deadline of each assignment (three in total) was reasonable, and students were allowed to bring one A4 size (including the back side of the page, either typed or handwritten) cheat sheet for both mid-term and final. However, students will have to spend a lot of time to comprehend the lecture notes as they are very unclear and incoherent.

Tutorials are a waste of time. Just attend 1 week's tutorial when you need to give your presentation, don't bother with the others.

(tutorial section) × 10%
(assignments) × 20%
(mid-term exam) × 30%
(final exam) × 40%

reviews.author: Bread
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers some of the basic Physics concepts that are needed in higher level Physics course. Due to the change in instructor, the contents may be slightly different from the previous years:
Mid-term
-Action Principle (Principle of Extreme Action, symmetry and conservation laws) (1 lesson)
-Special Relativity (5)
-General Relativity (1)
-Quantum Mechanics (2)
Final:
-Quantum mechanics (more details with calculation problems) (3)
-Atoms and molecules (atom orbitals, bonding) (2)
-Condensed matter (Crystal structure, heat capacity, energy band and conductors, semi-conductors) (2)
-Thermodynamics and statistical mechanics (Entropy) (2)
-Complexity (chaos, fractals, complex network) (1)
Not included in exam:
-Nuclear and particle physics (1)
-Cosmology (1)

As you can see, the course includes quite a lot of content--to the point I would say there are too much. Often times there are not enough time to go into details, and the professor may go over some topics too quickly (most students would probably agree on that for the action principle part) that the students may not understand completely.
reviews.comment_teaching: Being Professor Wang's first attempt at teaching an undergraduate course, I would say it is not bad. All of the notes for lecture are hand-written by himself, and he makes an effort to make the topics as interesting as possible, for example, by including jokes and his own drawings. He also encourages students to ask him questions, and even sets up an 'editable version of lecture notes' online, where students can post questions and he can addresses them.
reviews.comment_grading:
The mark calculation are as follow:
-9 Weekly Quiz:10%
-3 Assignments: 20%
-Mid-term: 30%
-Final: 40%
Around half of the marks for the exams are dictated by short response questions (e.g. write down the position eigenstate of a free particle), with others being longer questions that require detailed calculations. They are not too difficult: in both exams there are people who get full marks, and sometimes even more than that thanks to bonus marks.
As for the grading, I really want to know as well. For me, I get ~0.8 SD for mid term, ~1.4 SD for final, all full marks for assignment and 93% combining all quizzes, and I got an A. However, I know of a few who get below mean for mid-term, around the same marks as me for final, assignment and quizzes, and they get a an A as well. Based on this, I would make the following conjecture (though I have no statistics to back it up, do not quote me on this):
-The A range is quite wide, and it probably takes around 80% score on canvas to achieve (which is not as hard as it sounds)
-A+, however, is much harder to achieve, and probably only a few, if any, gets it.
-The mean is probably around B+
Plus, based on the general impression of the professor, the grading is probably quite good, so do not worry too much about getting very bad grades.

Assignments includes some longer response questions, similar to the exam. Try to start doing the assignments earlier: some (especially the third one on quantum mechanics) are really time consuming.

reviews.comment_content:
Unlike the usual conventional "modern physics" courses, which focus on mainly and only on introductory Special Relativity and Quantum Mechanics, Prof. Wang had completely redesigned the course syllabus to include a large array of topics, including:

1. Special relativity (6, E)
2. General relativity (1, A)

A: Advanced material, helps to distinguish  A+, A, A-.  


Although the SR and QM remained to be the most important part of the course, the course also introduces to the students a variety of topics linked directly to their future studies in physics and gives the student a taste of many more advanced & modern ideas in physics.

This redesigned syllabus has made the course become truly a board introduction to all of modern physics, but not just SR and QM, and in some sense, it even serves as an introduction to the "higher physics".

Unfortunately though, due to time constraint, my class only got to cover everything up to Statistical Physics (with an extra lecture on Cosmology, which was not tested). There are really a lot of topics to be covered in the course and many of them are really difficult (involve quite advanced mathematics), but I did learned a lot from them and I enjoyed the course very much.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Excellent. Almost perfect.

Prof. Wang is very passionate about teaching. He always talk with a big smile on his face, and he always try to improve his teaching by asking for feedback from the students. He always try to offer help to the students,. He officially hold an hour of office hour after each lecture to answer questions. You will see a lot of student surround him after each lecture to ask all kind of questions, and he will try to give a satisfactory answer to each of them.

As a physics professor, I think his way of teaching serves as the perfect example of what a college physics course is supposed to be. He wrote his own lecture notes, both typed in LaTeX and drawn on OneNote. Based on these notes, he deliver his lecture using a white board (no more hideous PPT's). He is very knowledgeable about all the contents of the course and even all of physics (and probably not just physics too...), as you can see from the content of the lecture notes, and he has the ability to present and explain his ideas very clearly (Well, at least most of the time). His lecture notes are really beautifully made, both in terms of the writing style, the very clear structure, the developments of physical ideas, the explanation of very physical details, and all the beautifully drawn figure. And all his lecture inherited perfectly all these good things of his lecture notes.

Though, there is still a few small defects in his teaching (that's why I said "almost" perfect):

(1) He tended to assume the students have more mathematical skills & knowledge than they actually have as a 2nd year student, and therefore often didn't give enough explanation on the mathematical details. I would suggest you don't hesitate to ask whenever you don't understand some math - when you don't know something, probably most of the class won't neither, and Prof. Wang will be more than happy to give you the explanation you want.

(2) Prof. Wang doesn't like to give exercises, because he think if you truly understand the physics, then you can apply them to solve the problem right away. I do partially agree with him about this, but unfortunately, this is just too much of an idealization. But on the other hand, because of the uniqueness of this course, it is really hard to find exercise anywhere that fit the scope of it. Hopefully it will get better after a few more runs of this course.


This course is truly amazing and fantastic. And the big idea behind all of this course, is to teach the student to understand and appreciate the beauty of physics and to view it as an art. Honestly, if you find yourself hating this course (well, apart from the grading / exam maybe), it is probably a good sign that physics is not for you. Physics is not about taking exams and calculating things; engineers and DSE students do that.
